basics.name: Norman Köhring
basics.label: Code Artist
basics.summary: Hi there! I am a freelancing programmer, OpenSource enthusiast and hacker based in Berlin, Germany.  I call myself a code artist because programming can and should be a creative process – and that is what I strive for when programming! Just like a painter loves to paint or a musician loves to sing or play an instrument, I love to think about concepts and patterns, and craft pieces of art with source code.

highlights: Development of a Kiosk system, including evaluation and programming.
Fullstack development with Nodejs, Vuejs, GeoJSON, interactive SVGs.

work.summary: Helping to build the Hamburg Open Online University
highlights: supported the MMKH team with consulting and programming
Used Ruby on Rails in the backend and Emberjs with SemanticUI in the frontend.

work.summary: FromAtoB is a platform that compares different modes of public transportation. Their web application is build with Vue.js and supported by Ruby and Go based APIs.
highlights: Introduced Vuejs as a framework for the new web application.
Used cutting edge web technologies and a modern tech stack.
Published multiple open-source packages for Vue.js, see https://www.npmjs.com/~koehr

work.summary: Zalando is an electronic e-commerce company operating in 14 European countries and worldwide with spin-offs and subsidiary companies.
highlights: created web presentations for special campaigns using React, HTML5 and CSS3

work.summary: Camunda BPM is an open-source platform for Business Process Management
highlights: developing bpmn.io, a BPMN rendering toolkit and interactive modeler using Javascript and SVG

work.summary: Blacklane offers a professional driver service in over 50 countries world-wide.
highlights: developed Blacklanes web-based booking system using AngularJS and NodeJS

work.summary: HERE Maps is a routing and discovery web application
highlights: developed the new HERE.com map web application using AngularJS, NodeJS and Express

work.summary: Coreon is a web based multilingual taxonomy editor
highlights: developed Coreon with Backbone, SVG and RubyOnRails

work.summary: Wimdu is an online marketplace and hospitality service, enabling people to lease or rent short-term lodging.
highlights: developed Wimdus super quick live search suggestions using ElasticSearch
developed an API and an experimental Cloud Management UI using cutting egde web technologies

work.summary: dMAS revolutionised advertisment fairs with visitor management, request/response system and more in one solution
highlights: created the first version prototype of dMAS using Sinatra (Ruby) and MongoDB
invented the QR code identification cards with shortcode fallback
managed deployment of system and database

work.summary: wecuddle is a web based flirt platform with live stream
developed a web based spreadsheet processing application

volunteer.summary: Global movement of free coding clubs for young people.
Berlin-based non-profit that trains and mentors EU resident and immigrant women who want to enter technology industry careers.
Organizes free RubyOnRails programming workshops for women* without prior experience in programming.

publications.name: Vuejs Reactivity From Scratch
publications.summary: Vuejs is the star newcomer in the Javascript Framework world. One of the more exciting features is its seemingly magic reactivity. Plain data objects in components magically invoke a rerender when a property changes. But we all know there is no fairydust involved, right? So how does it actually work?

publications.name: The Magic 0xC2
publications.summary: I built a web application with file upload functionality. Some Vue.js in the front and a CouchDB in the back. Everything should be pretty simple and straigt forward. But…

publications.name: The Price to Crack Your Password
publications.summary: Nearly six years ago, I wrote about password complexity and showed how long it takes to crack passwords per length.So, times changed and I thought about a reiteration of that topic, but instead focussing on the amount of money you need to crack the password.
